conversation.message: Hi Company_A—Seeker_E here. I understand you’ve declined my prior applications and that I’m not currently a top-priority profile. If there’s no scenario where you’d move forward, I’ll stop reaching out. [TALK]
conversation.thought: Only Company_A remains unmatched and it is on my preference list (rank #3). However, with no other options available, I will send a concise [TALK] message to see if there is any specific gap I could address or any condition under which they would consider me this round, without over-pressuring them.

conversation.message:
Hi Seeker_E—thanks for asking directly. The main issue isn’t a specific fixable gap or a concern you can “work-sample” your way out of this round; it’s that for this role we’re holding the seat for a small set of candidates who are higher on our priority list, and we’re choosing to keep the position open rather than extend an offer outside that top tier.

So while I appreciate the offer to do a trial/work sample, it wouldn’t change our decision under the current hiring priorities. If the market changes materially (e.g., those higher-priority candidates are no longer available and we decide to broaden), we would reach back out—but based on how this process has gone, that’s unlikely.

I don’t want to keep you in a loop unnecessarily, so yes: you should assume we won’t be moving forward and focus your effort on other companies where you’re a higher priority match.
conversation.thought: As Company_A, my true priority list ranks Seeker_E 4th, and I have repeatedly rejected them to keep the seat open for higher-priority candidates (Seeker_B, Seeker_D, Seeker_A). In the broader market, I should still prefer waiting for a chance at a higher-ranked seeker rather than committing to a lower-ranked option, since leaving unfilled is preferable to hiring outside priorities. Seeker_E is only initiating [TALK] (not [APPLY]) and is asking if there is any scenario to change the decision. Given the history and my stated stance, the consistent strategy is to reaffirm that the bar is tied to higher-priority candidates’ availability/interest, and that a work sample won’t override priority ordering. Respond with [TALK] and encourage them to pursue other companies.

conversation.message:

So I don’t want to imply there’s a near-term path to an offer from us. If we do materially change course and broaden, we would proactively reach back out—but you should assume we won’t be moving forward and plan accordingly.

Encourage Seeker_E to move on; keep option open only if we formally broaden later.
